key_findings: Illinois federal highway funding growing 25.4% from FY24 to FY26
New IIJA programs create opportunities for transformative projects

formula_analysis.title: FHWA Formula Fund Analysis for Illinois

NHPP.allocation_method: Formula based on lane-miles, vehicle-miles traveled on Interstate, and other factors
NHPP.flexibility: Can be used on NHS, Interstate resurfacing, bridge replacement
NHPP.illinois_advantage: High freight volume through Chicago benefits Illinois

STBG.allocation_method: Formula based on population and other factors, with sub-allocations by area size
STBG.flexibility: Most flexible federal program - roads, transit, bike/ped

HSIP.allocation_method: Formula based on fatalities and serious injuries
HSIP.focus: Data-driven safety improvements at high-crash locations
HSIP.illinois_priority: Urban intersections, rural highway segments with high crash rates

Bridge.allocation_method: Formula based on bridge deck area in poor condition
Bridge.illinois_situation: Significant aging bridge inventory, especially in Chicago metro
Bridge.priority: Structurally deficient and functionally obsolete bridges

Carbon_Reduction.allocation_method: Formula by state based on emissions
Carbon_Reduction.illinois_opportunity: Chicago transit + EV infrastructure = strong fit

sections.title: 💰 Overall Funding Trajectory
sections.finding: Illinois federal highway funding growing 25.4% from FY24 to FY26
sections.driver: IIJA (Infrastructure Investment & Jobs Act) increased authorization levels
sections.implication: More resources available for major projects and system preservation

sections.title: ⚖️ Program Flexibility
details: STBG focus: Any road, plus transit, bike/ped
sections.recommendation: STBG provides more local flexibility - maximize use for multimodal projects
sections.strategy: Consider shifting eligible projects to STBG to preserve NHPP for Interstate needs

sections.title: 🗺️ Geographic Distribution
details: STBG formula ensures both urban and rural receive dedicated funding
Population-based formulas naturally favor urban areas
sections.equity_note: Rural areas receive proportionally more per-capita due to higher maintenance costs per mile
sections.political_note: Bipartisan geographic balance built into formulas

sections.title: 🌱 Climate & Innovation Opportunities
sections.finding: New IIJA programs create opportunities for transformative projects

Carbon Reduction.illinois_strength: Chicago transit system ideal for carbon reduction investments

NEVI (EV Charging).requirement: Build out EV charging corridors on Interstate system
NEVI (EV Charging).illinois_advantage: Major freight corridors + Chicago hub = strong EV charging demand

sections.recommendation: Prioritize these programs - less competition, high visibility, future-focused

sections.title: 🌉 Bridge Investment Focus
sections.context: Illinois has significant aging bridge infrastructure
sections.strategy: Leverage dedicated bridge funds + competitive RAISE/INFRA for major projects

immediate: Maximize STBG flexibility for local priorities
Target new IIJA programs (Carbon, NEVI) for high-visibility projects
Coordinate district-level project lists with state MYP
strategic: Build coalition for competitive grants (RAISE, INFRA)
Align state/local projects with federal eligibility
Track obligation deadlines - use it or lose it
political: Bipartisan opportunities in bridge, safety programs
Committee members can influence competitive grants

next_steps: Map specific projects to available funding programs
Coordinate with IDOT on district priorities
